summary: This document is an email chain from November 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and the U.S. Attorney's Office (Southern District of New York) regarding requests for statements made by inmate Nicholas Tartaglione concerning Jeffrey Epstein's reported suicide attempt in July 2019. The prosecution agrees to produce some statements but refuses to provide video and other reports of the suicide attempt itself, deeming them irrelevant.

persons.name: Michael Bachrach
persons.context: Sends a brief email acknowledging receipt and stating they will review attached material.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Lead attorney making formal requests to the U.S. Attorney's Office for statements by Nicholas Tartaglione and all reports/video regarding Jeffrey Epstein's attempted suicide in July 2019.

persons.name: Aida Leisenring
persons.context: Copied on the email chain regarding the request for statements and materials related to Epstein's suicide attempt.

persons.name: Kenneth J. Montgomery
persons.context: Listed as a recipient in the initial email header.

persons.name: Tony Ricco
persons.context: Mentioned in Michael Bachrach's email sign-off ('Understood. Thank you.').

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Former police officer and inmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) who was interviewed regarding Jeffrey Epstein's reported suicide attempt. Statements attributed to him are the subject of the document request.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The document concerns the investigation into his reported attempted suicide at the MCC on or about July 23, 2019. Statements attributed to him conveying Tartaglione's words are also referenced.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Represents the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS). Responds to defense requests, agreeing to produce some statements but refusing video/reports of the suicide attempt.

connections.description: Barket is formally requesting records of statements made by Tartaglione, indicating he is likely representing or acting on behalf of Tartaglione.
Both were inmates at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). Tartaglione was interviewed about an event involving Epstein, and Epstein conveyed statements attributed to Tartaglione to MCC staff.
Engaged in correspondence regarding the production of evidence (Tartaglione's statements, Epstein suicide materials) under legal rules like Rule 16 and a protective order.
Bachrach's email sign-off ('Tony Ricco Understood.') suggests a professional collaboration or reporting line regarding the case materials.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Reported Suicide Attempt at MCC
events.description: The referenced event is Jeffrey Epstein's reported attempted suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. Inmate Nicholas Tartaglione was interviewed by BOP staff in the late hours of July 22 or early July 23 concerning this event.

events.title: Bruce Barket's Initial Request for Statements
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket sends an initial request to the U.S. Attorney's Office for any records, statements, or recordings of statements made by Nicholas Tartaglione regarding Epstein's suicide attempt.

events.title: Prosecution Response and Limited Production
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office agrees to produce a zip folder with reports of Tartaglione's statements (and those conveyed by Epstein) but refuses to produce video and other reports of the suicide attempt itself, citing relevance and Rule 16.

locations: Garden City, NY 11530 (Barket Epstein Kearon Aldea & LoTurco law firm address: 666 Old Country Road)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office possessed reports of statements made by inmate Nicholas Tartaglione, and statements attributed to Tartaglione that were conveyed to MCC staff by Jeffrey Epstein, regarding Epstein's July 2019 suicide attempt.
The prosecution refused to provide 'all the reports and video regarding Mr. Epstein's attempted suicide on July 22-23,' deeming them not relevant to the case or covered under discovery Rule 16.
Defense attorney Bruce Barket had previously sent a letter to the MCC asking for preservation of video related to Epstein's suicide attempt shortly after the event occurred.
The production of Tartaglione's statements was governed by a protective order, marking the materials as 'sensitive.'
The email chain reveals procedural hurdles for obtaining BOP/MCC records, requiring a Touhy letter, inmate release, and subpoena, with authority sought through the U.S. Attorney's Office.
